ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom.
Guest speakers
Presentations over zoom, research outside of class
On top of the virtual seminar, we watched videos to gain an introduction of the work of each guest.
virtual guest speakers, virtual content to review before discussions

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about the artistic process, from the time an artist gets an idea about a piece to the moment its of its debut. I also learned to be more creative and think outside the box.
I learned to appreciate art in its different formats! It was also eye-opening to see how subjective perception can be.

I learned about many different types of modern art I hadn't considered before, and I appreciated being able to hear from artists about their work. Additionally, I gained some knowledge into the history and background of art.
Learned how to research art in a new and interesting way.
A new way to research and acquire new information
challenging the meaning of research, exploring our artistic talents, examining the history of art, and learning from contemporary artists.

I gained a brand new way of thinking. This course completely changed my idea of what I consider art to be and taught me a new way of taking notes (which I will use in every class I take from this point on).

I developed my research skills through the exploration of various forms of art. The insights and knowledge I gained from listening to the work of other students influenced/changed my perspective and helped me to grow as a person.

I learned to...
apply outside research to art projects
connect outside interests (ex. scientific) and observations to art

I learned that...
art can be anything, and done by anyone
Learned about the different mediums of art and how they are used to convey a theme

I developed a much greater understanding of modern art, how modern art developed from the past, and how interpretation shapes art. I got much hands-on experience in developing art pieces from sources of inspiration in research and in expression. The guest speakers provided extremely valuable insight into their process and added a communal feeling to our artistic endeavors.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths:

Allows for creativity, professor is more than willing to help students in every way she can 

Weakness:

3 hour virtual format was a bit too long - could be hard to focus towards the end. A shorter class twice a week may have been more user-friendly.
This course doesn't have any weaknesses. The homework assignments and guests speakers were all really interesting.

The course expanded my thinking of art, and I feel I came away with a much more comprehensive idea of what art is. The main weakness of the course was regarding the online format since we weren't able to take any field trips, but that isn't the fault of the instructor.
It is very free flowing and was difficult to do art in the virtual format.
I loved how the teacher pushed me to try a new way of learning and research. The class time was quite long and it could sometimes be hard to pay attention.

Strengths: Instructor is awesome, topics are great, assignments are fun. 

Weaknesses: 3 hour continuous zoom calls are kind of hard. Perhaps splitting it over two days and having breaks during the meetings to stretch.

The strengths of this course were the guests, Karin's knowledge, and the setup (guest, presentations, etc.). It was an incomparable experience to hear from so many talented artists and to be able to interact with them. The only improvement I would make is to have a five minute break in the middle of class.

One strength of this course was its fluidity and acceptance of various types of work. It allowed me to pursue topics that I was interested in researching. Further, engagement was a strength of this course as well. Hearing other students present about topics they were passionate about was fascinating and enlightening.

strengths:
all guests were passionate and willing to talk to the class about their work
inclusive of students (or as prof. schneider would call us, "artists") of all backgrounds, in regards to experience and skill

weakness:
a few of the guests did not hold my attention as much as others; however, this is simply a personal preference

Strengths: Really great guest speakers that gave a lot of insight into their work. Weaknesses: A 3-hour Zoom lecture is just way too long to be able to stay focused on one topic for. I wish there was more room for experimentation with art during class rather than just all discussion for that length of time.

The lessons, exercises, and speakers were all great strengths. The teaching style, practice, and our presentations made it very enjoyable to experiment along the way and bring out the individuality of our pieces and thoughts.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think I would've enjoyed this seminar more if it was in person because a three hour zoom call can be a bit draining.

I believe that the online format worked well for the guest speakers' presentations and for our art research presentations. As mentioned before, the main thing is that we weren't able to take any field trips.
It was difficult to do hands-on learning in this class.
Everything was pretty good!
Having guest speakers on zoom was great.
I think this class did very well during the pandemic. Class was rarely interrupted by technology issues.

given the circumstances, the course was well-adjusted for the pandemic

however, I wish that classes were split into two shorter sessions, rather than one long session
due to the lack of face-to-face interaction, it was sometimes difficult to sit through a session lasting three hours

There were some technical issues that would come up, but Professor Schneider absolutely did everything she could at all times adapting to the pandemic learning environment. Overall I think it was very successful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Id recommend this course to a student pursuing the arts, or just a student studying another subject who wishes to step outside his/her comfort zone in the setting of a first year seminar.
I would definitely recommend this course to any student regardless of their intended major!
I would recommend this course because it broadened my horizons and made me a more knowledgeable person.
Yes!! Great course
Yes i would. Especially if they are stem and looking for something a little new.
Great course, absolutely take. Had a lot of fun and super low stress. Instructor is awesome and super supportive of everything you do.
I would 100% recommend this course to another student. It makes you step out of your comfort zone, especially because Karin makes you feel supported every step of the way.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because of its content, speakers, and assignments.

yes! yes!
prof. schneider is amazing. the class is amazing. everything is amazing.
to get the most out of the class, you will have to fully commit yourself to each synchronous session, as well as the work you do outside of the session. however, committing yourself is not difficult, nor is it time-consuming. this class has something to offer to everyone.

p.s. if you need a boost of confidence, whether in your artistic or academic abilities, take this class! prof. schneider welcomes any and all interpretations of the world, and teaches with the mindset that everyone has something of value to contribute

In an in-person setting, I think this class would've been super fun to be able to interact with the artists and the art other students were creating, so I would recommend it. But taking the seminar virtually really made it difficult to enjoy those discussions.

I really enjoyed the strong focus on experiential learning in art and focusing on the interpretation, perspective, and process elements. I felt that this greatly strengthened my individual creative efforts and I will certainly hold the practices with me going forward in my education and life.
